message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass suggests an external hemorrhoid, and the most likely artery to be the source of blood to the mass is the internal pudendal artery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest an external hemorrhoid. The blood supply to the external hemorrhoid comes from branches of the inferior rectal artery, which is a branch of the internal pudendal artery. Therefore, (B) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass and the symptoms suggest the most likely diagnosis is an external hemorrhoid. The internal pudendal artery is the most likely source of blood to this area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bright red blood in the stool and the bulging red nodule at the anal opening suggests an external hemorrhoid. The internal pudendal artery is the most likely source of blood to this area. The other arteries listed do not supply blood to this area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The perianal pain and bright red blood in stool suggests an external hemorrhoid. The internal pudendal artery supplies the anal canal and is the most likely source of blood to the mass found during examination. The other arteries listed do not supply blood to the anal canal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bulging, red nodule at the rim of the anal opening suggests an external hemorrhoid, which is primarily supplied by the inferior rectal artery, a branch of the internal pudendal artery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and presentation of the anal mass suggest an external hemorrhoid. The internal pudendal artery is the most likely source of blood supply to this area. None of the other arteries listed are located in the perianal region.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the bulging, red nodule at the rim of the anal opening suggests an external hemorrhoid. The internal pudendal artery is the most likely source of blood supply to the hemorrhoid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely diagnosis for this patient is an external hemorrhoid. The blood supply to the anus comes from the internal pudendal artery, which gives rise to the inferior rectal artery that supplies the anal canal and the external anal sphincter. Therefore, the internal pudendal artery is the most likely source of blood to the mass found during examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the bulging red nodule at the rim of the anal opening suggests an external hemorrhoid, which is usually supplied by the branches of the internal pudendal artery. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. The other arteries listed do not supply the anal region.
